title: Troubleshooting
text:
Problem: I cannot log in.

Double-check that you are using your school email and the correct password.

Problem: My session is stuck in “Queued”.

Refresh your page

Wait a few minutes; this can happen when servers are busy.

Problem: RStudio crashes or disconnects.

Try reducing the number of hours when launching your session.

Make sure you have a stable internet connection.

Problem: Quarto is not rendering.

Check that you saved your file with the .qmd extension.

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Auto data











Above are mpg vs horsepower, weight, and acceleration, with a blue linear-regression line fit separately to each. Can we predict mpg using these three?

Maybe we can do better using a model:
\[\texttt{mpg} \approx f(\texttt{horsepower}, \texttt{weight}, \texttt{acceleration})\]

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Notation

mpg is the response variable, the outcome variable, we refer to this as \(Y\)
horsepower is a feature, input, predictor, we refer to this as \(X_1\)
weight is \(X_2\)
acceleration is \(X_3\)
Our input vector is:

\(X = \begin{bmatrix} X_1 \\X_2 \\X_3\end{bmatrix}\)

Our model is

\(Y = f(X) + \varepsilon\)

\(\varepsilon\) is our error

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Why do we care about \(f(X)\)?

We can use \(f(X)\) to make predictions of \(Y\) for new values of \(X = x\)
We can gain a better understanding of which components of \(X = (X_1, X_2, \dots, X_p)\) are important for explaining \(Y\)
Depending on how complex \(f\) is, maybe we can understand how each component ( \(X_j\) ) of \(X\) affects \(Y\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
How do we choose \(f(X)\)?

What is a good value for \(f(X)\) at any selected value of \(X\), say \(X = 100\)? There can be many \(Y\) values at \(X = 100\).

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
How do we choose \(f(X)\)?

What is a good value for \(f(X)\) at any selected value of \(X\), say \(X = 100\)? There can be many \(Y\) values at \(X = 100\).

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
How do we choose \(f(X)\)?

What is a good value for \(f(X)\) at any selected value of \(X\), say \(X = 100\)? There can be many \(Y\) values at \(X = 100\).

There are 17 points here, what value should I choose for f(100). What do you think the blue dot represents?

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
How do we choose \(f(X)\)?

A good value is
\[f(100) = E(Y|X = 100)\]

\(E(Y|X = 100)\) means expected value (average) of \(Y\) given \(X = 100\)


This ideal \(f(x) = E(Y | X = x)\) is called the regression function

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Regression function, \(f(X)\)

Also works or a vector, \(X\), for example,

\[f(x) = f(x_1, x_2, x_3) = E[Y | X_1 = x_1, X_2 = x_2, X_3 = x_3]\]

This is the optimal predictor of \(Y\) in terms of mean-squared prediction error

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Regression function, \(f(X)\)

\(f(x) = E(Y|X = x)\) is the function that minimizes \(E[(Y - g(X))^2 |X = x]\) over all functions \(g\) at all points \(X = x\)


\(\varepsilon = Y - f(x)\) is the irreducible error
even if we knew \(f(x)\), we would still make errors in prediction, since at each \(X = x\) there is typically a distribution of possible \(Y\) values

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text: Regression function, \(f(X)\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Regression function, \(f(X)\)


Using these points, how would I calculate the regression function?



Take the average! \(f(100) = E[\texttt{mpg}|\texttt{horsepower} = 100] = 19.6\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Regression function, \(f(X)\)


This point has a \(Y\) value of 32.9. What is \(\hat\varepsilon\)?


\(\hat\varepsilon = Y - \hat{f}(X) = 32.9 - 19.6 = \color{red}{13.3}\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
The error
For any estimate, \(\hat{f}(x)\), of \(f(x)\), we have
\[E[(Y - \hat{f}(x))^2 | X = x] = \underbrace{[f(x) - \hat{f}(x)]^2}_{\textrm{reducible error}} + \underbrace{Var(\varepsilon)}_{\textrm{irreducible error}}\]

Assume for a moment that both \(\hat{f}\) and X are fixed.
\(E(Y − \hat{Y})^2\) represents the average, or expected value, of the squared difference between the predicted and actual value of Y, and Var( \(\varepsilon\) ) represents the variance associated with the error term
The focus of this class is on techniques for estimating f with the aim of minimizing the reducible error.
the irreducible error will always provide an upper bound on the accuracy of our prediction for Y
This bound is almost always unknown in practice

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Estimating \(f\)

Typically we have very few (if any!) data points at \(X=x\) exactly, so we cannot compute \(E[Y|X=x]\)
For example, what if we were interested in estimating miles per gallon when horsepower was 104.













💡 We can relax the definition and let
\[\hat{f}(x) = E[Y | X\in \mathcal{N}(x)]\]

Where \(\mathcal{N}(x)\) is some neighborhood of \(x\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Notation pause!

\[\hat{f}(x) = \underbrace{E}_{\textrm{The expectation}}[\underbrace{Y}_{\textrm{of Y}} \underbrace{|}_{\textrm{given}} \underbrace{X\in \mathcal{N}(x)}_{\textrm{X is in the neighborhood of x}}]\]


🚨 If you need a notation pause at any point during this class, please let me know!

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Estimating \(f\)
💡 We can relax the definition and let
\[\hat{f}(x) = E[Y | X\in \mathcal{N}(x)]\]


Nearest neighbor averaging does pretty well with small \(p\) ( \(p\leq 4\) ) and large \(n\)
Nearest neighbor is not great when \(p\) is large because of the curse of dimensionality (because nearest neighbors tend to be far away in high dimensions)




What do I mean by \(p\)? What do I mean by \(n\)?

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Parametric models
A common parametric model is a linear model
\[f(X) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_1 + \beta_2X_2 + \dots + \beta_pX_p\]

A linear model has \(p + 1\) parameters ( \(\beta_0,\dots,\beta_p\) )
We estimate these parameters by fitting a model to training data
Although this model is almost never correct it can often be a good interpretable approximation to the unknown true function, \(f(X)\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
The  red  points are simulated values for income from the model:

\[\texttt{income} = f(\texttt{education, senority}) + \varepsilon\]

\(f\) is the  blue  surface

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Linear regression model fit to the simulated data
\[\hat{f}_L(\texttt{education, senority}) = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1\texttt{education}+\hat{\beta}_2\texttt{senority}\]

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
More flexible regression model \(\hat{f}_S(\texttt{education, seniority})\) fit to the simulated data.
Here we use a technique called a thin-plate spline to fit a flexible surface

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
And even MORE flexible 😱 model \(\hat{f}(\texttt{education, seniority})\).

Here we’ve basically drawn the surface to hit every point, minimizing the error, but completely overfitting

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
🤹 Finding balance

Prediction accuracy versus interpretability

Linear models are easy to interpret, thin-plate splines are not

Good fit versus overfit or underfit

How do we know when the fit is just right?

Parsimony versus black-box

We often prefer a simpler model involving fewer variables over a black-box predictor involving them all

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy

We’ve fit a model \(\hat{f}(x)\) to some training data \(\texttt{train} = \{x_i, y_i\}^N_1\)
We can measure accuracy as the average squared prediction error over that train data

\[MSE_{\texttt{train}} = \textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{train}}[y_i-\hat{f}(x_i)]^2\]


What can go wrong here?


This may be biased towards overfit models

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy


I have some train data, plotted above. What \(\hat{f}(x)\) would minimize the \(MSE_{\texttt{train}}\)?

\[MSE_{\texttt{train}} = \textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{train}}[y_i-\hat{f}(x_i)]^2\]

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy


I have some train data, plotted above. What \(\hat{f}(x)\) would minimize the \(MSE_{\texttt{train}}\)?

\[MSE_{\texttt{train}} = \textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{train}}[y_i-\hat{f}(x_i)]^2\]

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy


What is wrong with this?


It’s overfit!

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy

If we get a new sample, that overfit model is probably going to be terrible!

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy

We’ve fit a model \(\hat{f}(x)\) to some training data \(\texttt{train} = \{x_i, y_i\}^N_1\)
Instead of measuring accuracy as the average squared prediction error over that train data, we can compute it using fresh test data \(\texttt{test} = \{x_i,y_i\}^M_1\)

\[MSE_{\texttt{test}} = \textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{test}}[y_i-\hat{f}(x_i)]^2\]

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text: Black curve is the “truth” on the left.  Red  curve on right is \(MSE_{\texttt{test}}\), grey curve is \(MSE_{\texttt{train}}\). Orange, blue and green curves/squares correspond to fis of different flexibility.

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text: Here the truth is smoother, so the smoother fit and linear model do really well

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text: Here the truth is wiggly and the noise is low, so the more flexible fits do the best

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Bias-variance trade-off

We’ve fit a model, \(\hat{f}(x)\), to some training data
Let’s pull a test observation from this population ( \(x_0, y_0\) )
The true model is \(Y = f(x) + \varepsilon\)
\(f(x) = E[Y|X=x]\)


\[E(y_0 - \hat{f}(x_0))^2 = \textrm{Var}(\hat{f}(x_0)) + [\textrm{Bias}(\hat{f}(x_0))]^2 + \textrm{Var}(\varepsilon)\]


The expectation averages over the variability of \(y_0\) as well as the variability of the training data. \(\textrm{Bias}(\hat{f}(x_0)) =E[\hat{f}(x_0)]-f(x_0)\)

As flexibility of \(\hat{f}\) \(\uparrow\), its variance \(\uparrow\) and its bias \(\downarrow\)
choosing the flexibility based on average test error amounts to a bias-variance trade-off



That U-shape we see for the test MSE curves is due to this bias-variance trade-off
The expected test MSE for a given \(x_0\) can be decomposed into three components: the variance of \(\hat{f}(x_o)\), the squared bias of \(\hat{f}(x_o)\) and t4he variance of the error term \(\varepsilon\)
Here the notation \(E[y_0 − \hat{f}(x_0)]^2\) defines the expected test MSE, and refers to the average test MSE that we would obtain if we repeatedly estimated \(f\) using a large number of training sets, and tested each at \(x_0\)
The overall expected test MSE can be computed by averaging \(E[y_0 − \hat{f}(x_0)]^2\) over all possible values of \(x_0\) in the test set.
SO we want to minimize the expected test error, so to do that we need to pick a statistical learning method to simultenously acheive low bias and low variance.
Since both of these quantities are non-negative, the expected test MSE can never fall below Var( \(\varepsilon\) )

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text: Bias-variance trade-off

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Notation

\(Y\) is the response variable. It is qualitative
\(\mathcal{C}(X)\) is the classifier that assigns a class \(\mathcal{C}\) to some future unlabeled observation, \(X\)
Examples:

Email can be classified as \(\mathcal{C}=(\texttt{spam, not spam})\)
Written number is one of \(\mathcal{C}=\{0, 1, 2, \dots, 9\}\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Classification Problem

What is the goal?


Build a classifier \(\mathcal{C}(X)\) that assigns a class label from \(\mathcal{C}\) to a future unlabeled observation \(X\)

Assess the uncertainty in each classification

Understand the roles of the different predictors among \(X = (X_1, X_2, \dots, X_p)\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Suppose there are \(K\) elements in \(\mathcal{C}\), numbered \(1, 2, \dots, K\)
\[p_k(x) = P(Y = k|X=x), k = 1, 2, \dots, K\] These are conditional class probabilities at \(x\)


How do you think we could calculate this?




In the plot, you could examine the mini-barplot at \(x = 5\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Suppose there are \(K\) elements in \(\mathcal{C}\), numbered \(1, 2, \dots, K\)
\[p_k(x) = P(Y = k|X=x), k = 1, 2, \dots, K\] These are conditional class probabilities at \(x\)

The Bayes optimal classifier at \(x\) is

\[\mathcal{C}(x) = j \textrm{ if } p_j(x) = \textrm{max}\{p_1(x), p_2(x), \dots, p_K(x)\}\]


Notice that probability is a conditional probability
It is the probability that Y equals k given the observed preditor vector, \(x\)
Let’s say we were using a Bayes Classifier for a two class problem, Y is 1 or 2. We would predict that the class is one if \(P(Y=1|X=x_0)>0.5\) and 2 otherwise

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
What if this was our data and there were no points at exactly \(x = 5\)? Then how could we calculate this?


Nearest neighbor like before!
This does break down as the dimensions grow, but the impact of \(\mathcal{\hat{C}}(x)\) is less than on \(\hat{p}_k(x), k = 1,2,\dots,K\)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
Accuracy

Misclassification error rate

\[Err_{\texttt{test}} = \textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{test}}I[y_i\neq \mathcal{\hat{C}}(x_i)]\] ::: {.incremental} * The Bayes Classifier using the true \(p_k(x)\) has the smallest error * Some of the methods we will learn build structured models for \(\mathcal{C}(x)\) (support vector machines, for example) * Some build structured models for \(p_k(x)\) (logistic regression, for example)
:::


the test error rate \(\textrm{Ave}_{i\in\texttt{test}}I[y_i\neq \mathcal{\hat{C}}(x_i)]\) is minimized on average by very simple classifier that assigns each observation to the most likely class, given its predictor values (that’s the Bayes classifier)

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
K-Nearest-Neighbors example



Here is a simulated dataset of 100 observations in two groups, blue and orange
The purple dashed line represents the Bayes decision boundary
The orange background grid indicates the region where the test observations will be classified as orange, and the blue for the blue
We’d love to be able to use the Bayes classifier to but for real data, we don’t know the conditional distribution of Y given X so computing the Bayes classifier is impossible
Alot of methods try to estimate the conditional distribution of Y given X and then classify a given observation to the class with the highest estimated probability
One method to do this is K-nearest neighbors

title: Trade-offs: Accuracy and interpretability, bias and variance
text:
KNN (K = 10)



Again, the way KNN works is if K = 10, it is finding the 10 closest observations and calculating the probability of being orange or blue and will classify that point as such
So here is an example of K nearest neighbors where K is 10

title: Welcome to Statistical Learning
text:
Supervised Learning

Dr. Lucy D’Agostino McGowan adapted from slides by Hastie & Tibshirani


outcome variable: \(Y\), (dependent variable, response, target)
predictors: vector of \(p\) predictors, \(X\), (inputs, regressors, covariates, features, independent variables)
In the regression problem, \(Y\) is quantitative (e.g price, blood pressure)
In the classification problem, \(Y\) takes values in a finite, unordered set (survived/died, digit 0-9, cancer class of tissue sample)
We have training data \((x_1, y_1), \dots, (x_N, y_N)\). These are observations (examples, instances) of these measurements

title: Welcome to Statistical Learning
text:
Supervised Learning

What do you think are some objectives here?


Objectives

Accurately predict unseen test cases
Understand which inputs affect the outcome, and how
Assess the quality of our predictions and inferences


Dr. Lucy D’Agostino McGowan adapted from slides by Hastie & Tibshirani

title: Welcome to Statistical Learning
text:
Unsupervised Learning

Dr. Lucy D’Agostino McGowan adapted from slides by Hastie & Tibshirani


No outcome variable, just a set of predictors (features) measured on a set of samples
objective is more fuzzy – find groups of samples that behave similarly, find features that behave similarly, find linear combinations of features with the most variation
difficult to know how well your are doing
different from supervised learning, but can be useful as a pre-processing step for supervised learning

title: Logging into RStudio Pro
text:
Follow these steps to access RStudio Pro:

Make sure you are connected to the WFU Network. This means you must be on the eduroam wireless network, or connected through the VPN if you are off-campus.

If you are off-campus, go through the VPN first: WFU VPN Instructions.

Go to login.deac.wfu.edu and sign in with your school email and password.
Once logged in, click the RStudio icon.
Set your working directory to /deac/sta/classes/sta363/YOUR-USERNAME where YOUR-USERNAME is replaced by the first part of your email address, i.e., mine is mcgowald because my email is mcgowald@wfu.edu
Set the number of hours to how long you plan to work on the project (I usually enter 4).
Click Launch.
The session will show as Queued for a moment. Once it is ready, the status will turn green and say Ready.
Click the Connect to RStudio Server button. You should now be in RStudio Pro.


Note: You are not required to use this setup (i.e., you can download RStudio and all the necessary packages locally). However, the focus of this class is not on technical setup, so we will not be able to spend time troubleshooting issues if you are not using the official setup described here.

text:
Before starting an assignment or exercise, always create or open a project:

To create a new project:

In RStudio, go to File > New Project.
Choose whether to create a project in a new directory or within an existing directory.
Navigate to the folder where you want your project
Click Create Project.

To open an existing project:

In RStudio, go to File > Open Project.
Browse to the .Rproj file of the project you want to open.
Select it and click Open.


This ensures all your files and settings are organized within the correct project environment.

title: Predicting handwritten numbers
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
load("data/zip.train.Rdata")
load("data/zip.test.Rdata")
This dataset consists of normalized handwritten digits, automatically scanned from envelopes by the U.S. Postal Service. The ultimate objective is to be able to predict which number is written so that the zip code can be automatically determined. The original scanned digits are binary and of different sizes and orientations; the images here have been deslanted and size normalized, resulting in 16 x 16 grayscale images (Le Cun et al., 1990). This data is obtained from the ElemStatLearn package.
Let’s see what kind of data this is.
class(zip.train)

[1] "matrix" "array"
It looks like this is a matrix. Let’s look at the the first 5 rows and 5 columns.
zip.train[1:5, 1:5]

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]   [,5]
[1,]    6   -1   -1   -1 -1.000
[2,]    5   -1   -1   -1 -0.813
[3,]    4   -1   -1   -1 -1.000
[4,]    7   -1   -1   -1 -1.000
[5,]    3   -1   -1   -1 -1.000
It looks like the first column contains the digit and the subsequent columns indicate values for the 256 pixels. Let’s tidy this up a bit.
zip_train <- zip.train %>%
  as_tibble(.name_repair = ~ c("label", glue::glue("pix_{1:256}")))

zip_test <- zip.test %>%
    as_tibble(.name_repair = ~ c("label", glue::glue("pix_{1:256}")))
Let’s plot a few. This code is adapted from a blog post by David Robinson.
pixels_gathered <- zip_train %>%
  slice(1:25) %>%
  mutate(instance = row_number()) %>%
  gather(pixel, value, -label, -instance) %>%
  tidyr::extract(pixel, "pixel", "(\\d+)", convert = TRUE) %>%
  mutate(pixel = pixel - 1,
         x = pixel %% 16,
         y = 16 - pixel %/% 16)

ggplot(pixels_gathered, aes(x, y, fill = value)) +
  geom_tile() +
  facet_wrap(~ instance + label)

title: Predicting handwritten numbers
text:
Predict 0
We are interested in creating a prediction model to determine whether the handwritten number is a 0.

First we create a recipe

recip <- zip_train %>% 
    recipe() %>% 
    update_role(starts_with("pix"), new_role = "predictor") %>%
    update_role(label, new_role = "outcome") %>%
    step_mutate(label = as.factor(label == 0)) ## Set the outcome to when the written number is equal to 0



Then we prep our recipe.

prepped <- recip %>% 
    prep(retain = TRUE)



Then we create our training data and testing data

train <- prepped %>% 
    juice()

test <- prepped %>% 
    bake(new_data = zip_test)



Now we specify our model
We are fitting a decision tree.

tree_fit <- fit(
    decision_tree(mode = "classification", tree_depth = 3),
    formula = formula(prepped),
    data = train,
    engine = "rpart")



Assess the model

results <- tibble(
    truth = test$label,
    estimate = predict(tree_fit, test) %>% 
      pull(.pred_class)
  )

metrics(results, truth = truth, estimate = estimate) %>% 
  knitr::kable()




.metric
.estimator
.estimate




accuracy
binary
0.9362232


kap
binary
0.7861534







Create a confusion matrix
What is the false positive rate? What is the false negative rate?

conf_mat(results, truth = truth, estimate = estimate)[[1]] %>% 
  as_tibble() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(Prediction, Truth, alpha = n)) + 
  geom_text(aes(label = n), alpha = 1, size = 10) +
  labs(title = "Confusion matrix")










Plot the tree
Which pixels are involved in this prediction?

library(rpart.plot)
rpart.plot(tree_fit$fit, roundint = FALSE)

To create a new Quarto document:

Be sure that you are in the correct project for the exercise or assignment. If you need help creating a new project here are some tips.

Save the file to your project directory

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text: Quarto is the next-generation version of R Markdown that combines code, results, and narrative text into dynamic documents. This guide covers the essentials you’ll need for STA 312.

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Document Structure
Every Quarto document starts with a YAML header (between --- lines) that contains metadata:
---
title: "My Statistical Analysis"
author: "Your Name"
date: today
format: html
execute:
  echo: true
  warning: false
---

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Basic Markdown Syntax

Headers
# Header 1 (largest)
## Header 2
### Header 3
#### Header 4


Text Formatting

Bold text: **bold text** or __bold text__
Italic text: *italic text* or _italic text_
Code text: `code text`
Links: [link text](URL)



Lists
Unordered lists:
- Item 1
- Item 2
  - Sub-item
  - Sub-item
Ordered lists:
1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
R Code Chunks
The power of Quarto comes from embedding R code directly in your document.

Basic Code Chunk
Code chucks start with {r}.
```{r}
# Your R code here
x <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
mean(x)
```


Code Chunk Options
Your code chunks can have options that are written in YAML style starting with a #| at the beginning of the line.
```{r}
#| label: data-setup
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false

# Load libraries and data
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
```


Common Chunk Options

#| echo: false: Hide code, show output

#| eval: false: Show code, don’t run it

#| include: false: Run code, hide everything

#| message: false: Hide messages

#| warning: false: Hide warnings

#| fig-width: 8 and #| fig-height: 6: Control plot dimensions

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Inline R Code
You can include R results directly in text using `r`:
The mean of our data is `r round(mean(x), 2)`.

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Mathematical Expressions
Quarto uses LaTeX syntax for mathematical notation:

Inline Math
Use single dollar signs for inline math: $x^2 + y^2 = z^2$


Display Math
Use double dollar signs for centered display math:
$$\bar{x} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i$$


Common Statistical Notation








Concept
LaTeX Code
Rendered Output




Mean
$\bar{x}$
\(\bar{x}\)


Standard deviation
$\sigma$
\(\sigma\)


Regression equation
$y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon$
\(y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon\)


Sums
$\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
\(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i\)


Square root
$\sqrt{n}$
\(\sqrt{n}\)


Fractions
$\frac{a}{b}$
\(\frac{a}{b}\)


Subscripts
$x_i$
\(x_i\)


Superscripts
$x^2$
\(x^2\)


Matrices
$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$
\(\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}\)

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Tables

Simple Tables
| Variable | Mean | SD   |
|----------|------|------|
| Height   | 68.2 | 3.1  |
| Weight   | 155  | 22.5 |


Tables from R Code
```{r}
#| label: summary-table
#| tbl-cap: "Summary Statistics"

library(knitr)
summary_stats <- data.frame(
  Variable = c("Height", "Weight"),
  Mean = c(68.2, 155.0),
  SD = c(3.1, 22.5)
)
kable(summary_stats)
```

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Figures

Plots with Captions
```{r}
#| label: fig-scatter
#| fig-cap: "Relationship between height and weight"
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-height: 4

ggplot(data, aes(x = height, y = weight)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  labs(x = "Height (inches)", y = "Weight (lbs)")
```

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Cross-References
You can reference figures, tables, and equations:

Reference a figure: @fig-scatter

Reference a table: @tbl-summary

Reference an equation: @eq-regression

For equations with labels:
$$y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x + \epsilon$$ {#eq-regression}

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Callout Blocks
Quarto provides special callout blocks for important information:
::: {.callout-note}
This is a note callout.
:::

::: {.callout-warning}
This is a warning callout.
:::

::: {.callout-important}
This is an important callout.
:::

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Rendering Your Document
To render your Quarto document:

In RStudio: Click the “Render” button

Command line: Run quarto render filename.qmd

Preview: Use quarto preview filename.qmd for live preview

title: Quarto Quick Reference Guide
text:
Tips for Statistical Writing

Always explain your code: Use comments (#) and narrative text
Round numbers appropriately: Use round() function for inline code
Label your chunks: Makes debugging easier
Include figure captions: Helps with interpretation

Functions are (most often) verbs, followed by what they will be applied to in parentheses:

install.packages("package_name")
library(package_name)

Accessibility Policy
Wake Forest University provides reasonable accommodations for students with disabilities. Academic accommodations are coordinated through the Center for Learning, Access, and Student Success (CLASS). Discussion:

title: Policies
text:
Honor code
Wake Forest University is committed to a culture of academic integrity. As a part of this community, you share the responsibility for creating a place of honesty, intellectual curiosity, and individual accountability. As you committed to with your honor pledge signature, you agree “not to deceive any member of the community; not to steal, cheat, or plagiarize on academic work; and not to engage in any other form of academic misconduct.” If you have questions about documenting your work, working with external sources, working with peers on assigned work, etc., consult with me as soon as possible. Instances of academic dishonesty will be referred to the Honor and Ethics Council.

Sharing code & responses

There are many online resources for sharing code (for example, StackOverflow) - you may use these resources but must explicitly cite where you have obtained code (both code you used directly and “paraphrased” code / code used as inspiration). Any reused code that is not explicitly cited will be treated as plagiarism.
Rather than copying someone else’s work, ask for help. You are not alone in this course!
